social_posts.post_text:
While digestive symptoms are a sign it’s time to work on your gut health, the bacteria in your gut also affect many other systems in the body. Hidden signs it might be time to take a root cause approach to your gut health:

- Poor thyroid health
-Chronic pain and inflammation
-Anxiety
-Heavy and painful periods
-Blood sugar imbalances
-Auto-immune conditions

This is not to say that gut health is the only thing that contributes to these symptoms and conditions, but it’s certainly a piece of the puzzle. Questions? Leave them below.

Struggling with your thyroid health? I see a lot of clients with clinical and subclinical hypothyroidism symptoms, such as:

* Fatigue
* Weight gain
* Hair loss
* Feeling anxious and low mood
* Brain fog
* Dry skin 
Here’s what you likely haven’t been told. Thyroid conditions have a root cause. Your thyroid sets your metabolic rate. It reacts to stressors in your environment and most commonly downregulates to conserve resources.

What are some things that can inhibit thyroid function?
* Stress & Adrenal disfunction
* Poor blood sugar metabolism
* Hormonal imbalances
* Gut infections & poor digestive health
* Liver congestion
* Inflammation 
If you have a thyroid condition or suspect you do, you must investigate the above, and often you won’t completely feel better, even on medication, until you do.

Why does gut health matter so much when it comes to thyroid health?

Healthy bacteria are needed to convert inactive thyroid hormone to active thyroid hormone. A lot of this conversions happens in the liver, but the gut is important too.

Yeast, bacteria, parasitic overgrowth, gut infections, and intestinal permeability can crowd out the healthy bacteria needed for this thyroid hormone conversion.

Any inflammation or pathogen in the gut can also impair adrenal function, creating systemic inflammation. Inflammation is one of the top contributors to impaired thyroid function.

Poor digestion can also deplete thyroid nutrients, such as zinc selenium, tyrosine, vitamin A, and vitamin D.

If you’re constipated, you are likely not clearing estrogen well, and high estrogen can slow thyroid function.
 
You can’t ignore gut health when it comes to thyroid health.

Suspect there’s something off with your thyroid? It’s a sign it’s time to dig a little deeper into your health.

Cortisol and inflammation can inhibit the conversion of inactive thyroid hormone to active thyroid hormone (T4→ T3) and inhibit TSH.

What are some stressors that can contribute to high cortisol levels beyond the stress of our day-to-day lives, which can certainly be a factor as well:

* Infections stemming from the gut ( you don’t have to have classic gut symptoms to have an infection in the gut) 
* EBV 
* Heavy metals 
* An Inflammatory diet 
* Mold exposure

Let’s round out our thyroid health series. Labs to assess optimal thyroid function.

When it comes to thyroid health, most of the time, TSH (and sometimes T4) are the only markers that are tested. TSH alone is a poor marker of overall thyroid health. If you suspect something is happening with your thyroid but you’ve only had TSH tested, it’s time to dig a little deeper.

TSH is produced and released by the pituitary gland in the brain and not by the thyroid gland. When the pituitary gland secretes TSH, it causes the thyroid gland to release more T3 and T4. When you’re only measuring TSH, you’re measuring the communication between the thyroid and the brain, not the thyroid gland itself.

Don’t get me wrong, TSH is an important marker, but it shouldn’t be the only marker that’s looked at.

TSH is also often when of the last things to go offline. There can be dysfunction with the thyroid gland long before TSH goes offline, and only looking at TSH misses this early dysfunction; meanwhile, you can have thyroid symptoms.

As I’ve mentioned in my previous posts, thyroid conditions are seldom a root cause. Usually, the thyroid gland reacts to another stressor in the body. The additional labs consider these main stressors.

I saw dozens of doctors (yes, even functional medicine doctors) and therapists, and nobody told me or showed me that my mental wellness and the anxiety that consumed me was so much more than just in my head. That it was rooted in my physical body—depleted by stress, blood sugar dysfunction, poor thyroid and adrenal health, minerals loss, and poor gut health—and my severely deregulated nervous system.
 
And it’s why it took me a decade to heal…
 
If you’re looking for a proven plan that addresses the root causes of feelings of anxiety, DM me “plan.”
 The waitlist for The Anxiety Blueprint is open.

Your entire life can change in a year, and true healing is possible. 
Unfortunately, most of the time, we don’t even allow ourselves to heal. We cut ourselves off before we even begin.

We’re often fed harmful messages in a culture obsessed with quick fixes.
 We are told popping a probiotic will miraculously cure our decade-long digestive struggle when true healing is much deeper. Probiotics can be helpful, and I use a wide range of probiotics in practice, but they are only one single tool in an approach that requires multiple layers actually to get to the root cause.
 
We are sold a story that calorie cutting is the only way to lose weight or elimination diets are the way to reduce your symptoms. If your body is already under stress or inflammation, both of these approaches are likely only to leave you further in a hole that’s tough to climb out of.
 
Truly healing is possible, but I’ve never seen an approach of trying random elimination diets or probiotics work. Healing requires a systematic plan of root cause testing, personalized supplements, nervous system support, sleep hygiene, and a diet that promotes blood sugar balance, microbiome diversity, and mood stabilization.

Let’s file this under beneficial information essential to our overall well-being that somehow we are never taught and rarely asked about at annual physicals. 
If you do not have a full and complete bowel movement 1-3 times a day, every single day, that’s a red flag. 🚩 🚩🚩

Rabbit pellets are not complete bowel movements, nor are MiraLAX or other laxatives the answer.

Bowel movements are phase three of liver detoxification. Daily bowel movements are essential for the following, to name just a few things: 
→Hormone health, particularly estrogen detoxification
→Removing toxic waste packaged up by your liver (think environmental toxins as well as metabolic waste products)
→ Reducing brain fog and fatigue
→ Skin health

Some common root causes of constipation I see in practice: 
→Slow metabolism resulting from mineral depletion due to long-term stress
→Sluggish thyroid function
→Poor gut health: parasites, dysbiosis, or gut infections
→Dehydration or inadequate fiber intake
→Lack of exercise
→Weak pelvic floor health

If you’re ready to work on your gut health and mental wellness, the VIP priority list for The Anxiety Blueprint is now open. DM me “blueprint” to get on this list and get first access to enroll in the next round of this program.

If you’ve heard magnesium is excellent for anxiety, constipation, and period pain, you’ll want to listen to this reel.

Magnesium is responsible for hundreds, if not thousands, of reactions and can be beneficial for sleep, blood sugar, gut health, nervous system support, energy production, muscle relaxation, and vitamin D status, to name a few. I use magnesium a lot in practice!

But taking large doses of magnesium can also affect other minerals, such as sodium and potassium, which are also needed for a healthy stress response.

The biggest takeaway, all minerals affect each other. If you’re taking magnesium, you also likely need to consider other minerals like sodium and potassium or ensure you have the adequate status of these minerals.

What is the best way to test minerals? Through a hair tissue mineral analysis. That’s what I use in practice with my private coaching clients and my group program, The Anxiety Blueprint.

Nothing changes if nothing changes.
 
If you’re experiencing digestive symptoms like constipation, stomachaches, reflux, loose stools, gas, bloating, and feelings of anxiety, 2023 will look like 2022 unless you do something different.
 
Let The Anxiety Blueprint be what you do differently.
 
The Anxiety Blueprint is a one-of-a-kind group coaching program that combines personalized root causes testing, expert coaching and guidance, and community support to help you get to the root cause of your digestive symptoms and feelings of anxiety.
 
DM me “blueprint” is to get on The VIP Priority list to get first to access The Anxiety Blueprint when the doors open again this spring.

[Boston] Join me at @somayogacenter on Sunday for a workshop about a functional and integrative approach to anxiety. 
If you’re looking for a different approach to feelings of anxiety and gut health, this workshop is for you. 

You’ll leave the workshop with specific nutrition and lifestyle strategies to:

* Improve gut health and reduce feelings of anxiety.
* Balance blood sugar to improve mood.
* Promote the growth of mood-enhancing beneficial bacteria in the gut.
* Optimize digestion to reduce gas, bloating, and GI symptoms (like loose stools and constipation).

Link in bio to register. DM me with any questions.

Despite what you’ve likely been told, symptomatic periods like severe cramping and heavy periods or irregular cycles are rarely the underlying cause of a problem.

Hormones are usually responding to other issues, so you can’t just treat hormones by themselves. Unfortunately, our medical model usually only gives women one of two choices: 1.)  to shut hormones down entirely by going on oral contraceptives or to use HRT when hormones are low or off. 
Symptoms are just a way for your body to tell us something is off.

Common root causes of symptomatic periods and female hormone imbalances:
1.) GI inflammation from pathogens and dysbiosis in the gut
2.) Poor liver detoxification or toxic burden (I often see a significant connection between mycotoxins and period problems)
3.) Mental and emotional stress or inflammation coming from diet
 
I usually see a combination of all three root causes in clinical practice.
 
Please note: I’m not against hormonal BC. If you’re on BC and love it, you do you. What I’m against is women being given no other options, when it is repeatedly aggressively pushed on clients despite them saying they would like to try different options and not being told about any of the potential long-term implications of BC use, including changes to the gut microbiota and nutrient depletion, amongst many other side-effects too long even to list.
 
There are other options, which include getting to the root cause.

I rarely need to use harsh elimination diets in practice to help clients resolve their digestive symptoms like feelings of anxiety, gas, bloating, and constipation. In fact, I don’t recommend them as a long-term solution to your digestive symptoms.

The more experience I gain in clinical practice, and the more I learn, the more I move away from what’s taught as part of traditional nutrition and dietetics training and even some functional medicine training because more supportive and effective options are available to you. The more I learn, the better I can do.

Elimination diets like LowFod Map can be incredibly stressful, emotionally draining, and counterproductive to your long-term goals of gut healing, not to mention it’s designed to be a short-term tool. Yes, in the short-term, elimination diets may be beneficial for some if done correctly and while also working on the root cause, but in the long-term, elimination diets can cause more harm than good. Yet, I’ve found this critical point is seldom communicated to clients by prescribers.

There’s a better way.

If you’d like to dive deeper, I invite you to read on.

This is why I use functional medicine lab testing, specifically stool testing and Hair Tissue Mineral Analysis, to help clients get to the root cause of their digestive and mood symptoms.

The next round of The Anxiety Blueprint starts later this spring, and we dive deep into functional medicine labs and the gut-brain connection to help you resolve the root cause of your symptoms. DM “Blueprint” to hop on the VIP Priority List to access exclusive discounts when the doors open.

Modern medicine: diet, lifestyle and gut health have nothing to do with mental wellness.

The research: 🙃

Are you feeling anxious? This one is for you.

So many aspects of your health contribute to your mental wellness beyond genetics, yet our modern healthcare approach typically only focuses on this one aspect you can’t control.

While genetics may certainly play a role, it doesn’t tell us the whole picture for many, and unfortunately, it leaves you feeling like there must be more to the story.

This is precisely why I created The Anxiety Blueprint, a group coaching program designed to help you overcome feelings of anxiety once and for all.

In this program, I help you improve, not just manage your mental wellness, by getting to the root cause.

The VIP Priority List is now open—link in bio to join.

Hop on this list to get first access to the program when the doors open and exclusive discounts not found anywhere else.

The VIP list closes on March 17, and the next round of The Anxiety Blueprint starts in April. Are you in?

The majority of women in my practice are dealing with some sort of constipation, some for decades.

The only solutions these women have been given are a stool softener or Miralax from conventional healthcare or a boatload of supplements from other functional medicine practitioners without focusing on diet, blood sugar, nervous system support, sleep, or stress management. 
I don’t know which approach is worse. Honestly, both are equally and very damaging.

You do not have a stool softener deficiency, and it’s not a root cause approach if you’re struggling with constipation and you haven’t been given guidance on diet, sleep, and nervous system support, to name a few. I don’t know where these practitioners who test and only provide supplements are getting their training, but that’s not functional medicine and it’s likely a more expensive option in the long run because it can keep you stuck in a broke cycle for years.

Your practitioner might not be trained (or properly trained) in helping you get to the root cause of constipation, but that doesn’t mean you don’t have one.

Which root cause(s) apply to you can be determined with a thorough evaluation from a sharp and well-trained practitioner and the proper testing.

If you’re ready to get to the root of chronic constipation and feelings of anxiety with a proven method that works, early-bird pricing for The Anxiety Blueprint opens Monday, and you must be on the waitlist to get access. Link in bio to join. Early access ends on Thursday, and once it’s over, it’s over.

Why wait any longer? No, seriously, why wait any longer?

Which one are you?

No judgement.

DM me 💩, and let's chat about how we can get you feeling better.

Welcome to the place on the internet where we validate your experience.

On average, it will take ten years for women in the US to receive a proper endometriosis diagnosis, arguably one of the most painful conditions that women experience.

Women are also more likely than men to be misdiagnosed in various conditions ranging from heart conditions to chronic pain.

While our healthcare system is, unfortunately, failing women in many ways, we hold responsibility too.

In a society that reinforces the message that women should put themselves last, you can choose a different outcome for yourself.

In fact, to truly show up for your family, your career, and anything else you desire in life, it all starts with your own health.

Women are incredible, and the amount we are able to hold is unmatched—but let’s stop trying to convince ourselves that laying on the couch in extreme period pain, being scared to leave the house because of heavy bleeding every month, constant exhaustion, dealing with uncomfortable bloating, stomach pain, trouble going to the bathroom or constantly running to the bathroom, and feeling anxious all the time is somehow normal and somehow not affecting your quality of life or your ability to show up for those you love.

What if you started to think it was selfish not to fully take care of yourself?

Your gut and your brain are connected physically, biochemically, and emotionally. Is your gut health affecting your mental well-being?

Join me for a free training on Thursday, where we'll dive deep into the gut-brain connection.

DM me "training" for the link to register!

You'll walk away knowing:
 
✅Why your gut health may be the missing piece to your mental wellness, even if you feel you've tried everything else!

✅Why you may still be anxious after going to therapy and reading aaaall of the self-help books.
 
✅The science behind the gut-brain connection and why a balanced microbiome is critical in addressing feelings of anxiety, boosting your mood, and managing stress.

✅The critical steps overlooked or skipped that likely hold vital clues to determining your root cause of symptoms.

✅How the brain and the gut are physically, emotionally, and biochemically connected.

✅How to create an EFFECTIVE PLAN OF ACTION and determine your IMMEDIATE first steps.

I'm just going to come out and say that a conventional approach to anxiety sometimes makes no sense. It's based on the assumption that what happens in the brain stays in the brain and that our physical health doesn't affect our mental well-being. Yet our body and brain are directly connected—in one significant way through the gut-brain connection.

Many common root causes of anxiety can be traced back to nervous system dysregulation and poor gut health. Yes, even hormone imbalances can start in the gut.

Join me Thursday for a live training on the gut-brain connection. You'll walk away knowing why your gut health is essential to your mental well-being, what to do to improve gut health, and the critical steps you've likely missed.

DM me "training" for the link to sign up, and once you've signed up, please share this event with a friend.

It can take 17 years for research to reach clinical practice, meaning that the last decade of research on the gut-brain connection and how chronic stress affects microbial diversity and intestinal permeability (commonly referred to as “leaky gut”) isn’t being utilized. Reduced microbial diversity and intestinal permeability are associated with poor mental well-being, inflammation, food sensitivities, and GI symptoms like gas, bloating, and both sluggish bowel movements and urgency.

 While I’m typically a huge fan of both conventional medicine and functional medicine working together for your benefit, unfortunately, the research on the gut-brain connection and how it can help you isn’t being utilized by many providers.

Let’s change that. Join me on Thursday for free training on the gut-brain connection. You’ll learn why this might be your missing link, even if you feel like you’ve tried everything else. DM me “training” for the link to register.

There are so many common symptoms that society and are medical system has labeled as "normal" and "not that bad' but are so far from normal and keep too many women from reaching the best, most abundant of themselves.

There's nothing normal about experiencing fatigue, brain fog, gas, bloating, feelings of anxiety, or constipation every single day. Feelings of anxiety can be expected when there's something to be excited about, you've got a big presentation coming up, or you're simply doing something new. Still, when it's something you're experiencing every single day, it's time to start to dig into the root causes of physical imbalances in your body that contribute to your emotional symptoms—and that begins in the gut!

The doors to The Anxiety Blueprint are officially open for this week only! If you're looking for a proven system that works to get to the root of your digestive health to eliminate your symptoms once and for all and a program to rebalance your nervous system, The Anxiety Blueprint is for you!

Did you know your gut is often referred to as your “second brain?” It’s true! 🤯

In this week’s episode of Electric Ideas, I connect with Kerri Axelrod, a functional medicine nutritionist and nationally recognized expert on the gut-brain axis. We dive deep into the connection between our gut and brain, especially how it impacts mood and anxiety.

Tune in today on Spotify, Apple or wherever you enjoy streaming. And tell us below - what did you take away from this conversation? 👇
Swipe through for symptoms of poor gut health beyond your daily bowel movements.

Stomach acid is the unsung hero of good gut health.

I’ve got a big newsletter going out this week, all about how low stomach acid might be one of the root causes of chronic skin conditions like psoriasis, acne, and eczema, and other ways to tell if your stomach acid is low.

Ready to unlock the secrets to healthier skin? Comment below “newsletter,” and we’ll send you the link to receive this information straight to your inbox. 💌💪

image_entities.entity: bind me to the medicine of love.

social_posts.post_text: Peep that third slide though 👀

That second slide is where the gold is. 🔑If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is.

Are probiotics helpful? Absolutely, they can be. Will they alone heal your gut? Unlikely.

Mysterious gut symptoms aren’t always that mysterious, and there’s more you can do when you’re told your labs are normal besides eating more fiber, being put on a PPI, and taking Miralax. Don’t get me wrong, fiber is essential for GI health, but it isn’t often a cure-all and PPI and laxatives can often do more harm than good.

Some of the most common root causes of GI symptoms, such as bloating, constipation, loose stools, and reflux that I see in practice are:p

•Low motility and digestive dysfunction
•Low stomach acid
•Gut pathogens
•Candida overgrowth, which can usually be attributed to mold exposure or some of the root causes above
•Hormonal birth control use

I’m opening up two spots for 1:1 clients to start in September. If you’re struggling with ongoing “unexplained” digestive issues, head to the link in my bio to schedule an assessment call.

All bloating is not created equal.🙅🏻‍♀️

You can spend a lot of time, money, and frustration playing a never-ending game of treasure hunt trying to figure out the exact foods that are contributing to your bloating, which are likely always changing, or you can use that energy getting to work on the root cause.

If you’re feeling bloated after:

Protein-rich meals → you likely need stomach acid support

Eating starches, plant fibers, salads → you likely need pancreatic enzyme support

Eating high-fat meals → your gallbladder might need support

Eating anything → it’s time to think SIBO, dysbiosis in the large intestine, the environment you’re eating in (don’t overlook this), the additives in your food, or motility and constipation issues.

Spoiler alert, you can have more than one root cause of bloating, and I most often see that as the case in my clinic.

If you’re ready to resolve your bloating for good, click the link in my bio to schedule an assessment call. Questions on bloating? Leave them in the comments below.

Decoding What Your Bloating Might Be Telling You. Save this post for the next time you're feeling bloated.

The timing of your bloating might provide clues to a potential root cause.

While I advocate for testing rather than guessing or supplementing blindly, focusing on general patterns related to when your bloating occurs can be a helpful starting point.

An important note: Some distension after meals can be perfectly normal, but painful or uncomfortable bloating is absolutely not normal and usually indicates that deeper support is needed. With that said, there’s a balance between hyper-vigilance, which can often be rampant in the functional space, and just being told that your bloating is “normal” and then being sent on your way.

Which slide was most helpful? 2, 3, 4, or 5? What did I miss when it comes to understanding your bloating?

Typically, food is not the root cause of bloating but a symptom. I rarely recommend a long-term approach that requires you to remove a bunch of foods from your diet to solve bloating because you’re just chasing an ever-changing symptom and not addressing the root cause.

With that said, there are often MANY ingredients added to foods marketed as “healthy” that can contribute to gas and bloating, especially if you are already struggling with GI issues.

I have a newsletter going out next week, all about foundational—and often overlooked—strategies to deal with bloating. These strategies are the starting points you must consider if you’re struggling with bloating, and they are the ones that 99% of the people I work with skip over before we start implementing them.

Comment “newsletter” below, and we’ll send you the link to receive my foundational bloating strategies when the newsletter goes out.

Please note, I’m not saying never eat takeout, get meal delivery, or dine at restaurants. Life isn’t so black-and-white, and honestly, that approach takes away much of life’s joy. It isn’t a standard I would hold myself to, so it’s not something I promote. However, if you find yourself eating 2-3 meals out every week, or relying on meal delivery services, and struggling with bloating, the excessive processed sodium, additives, and sugar you’re likely consuming might be something to evaluate.

If you’ve given an elimination diet not one, but two tries and you’re still grappling with those nagging symptoms, chances are the issue isn’t in your plate. It’s in your gut.

It’s your gut that needs the support.

You have to focus on rebalancing the gut to eliminate your symptoms—no amount of food restriction will get you there. I know your practitioner likely told you something different, and it’s likely why you’re still stuck.

If it didn’t work the first time, it’s unlikely to work the second, the third, or the fourth time, and continuing with elimination diets will probably leave you more frustrated and with a lot more wasted time.

What to do instead? It depends on what’s going on in your gut and your root cause. Click the link in my bio to schedule an assessment call, and let’s eliminate your symptoms for good.

Why I Don’t Recommend Self-Treating with Berberine.👆🏻

If you’re looking for support with your gut health and want to know what to do instead, comment ‘gut’ below. I’ll send you a link to receive my newsletter going out tomorrow that covers one of the most foundational steps to digestive health that most people are completely missing.

This one might ruffle some feathers, especially among conventionally minded practitioners 👀, but IBS is a diagnosis for a collection of symptoms that Western medicine can’t fully explain.

It doesn’t mean your symptoms aren’t real. Your symptoms are VERY real, but IBS is a diagnosis of exclusion. Essentially, it means we can’t figure out what’s wrong with you, so we’ll slap you with this diagnosis and send you on your way.

That’s why clients in our practice spend years going through the revolving door of doctor visits, visits to the ER, lab tests after lab tests coming back “normal,” only to deal with sometimes debilitating:

❌Abdominal pain
❌Cramping
❌Constipation or diarrhea (or both)
❌Gas
❌Bloating
❌Food sensitivities
❌Fatigue

In almost every single IBS client we work with, we find some type of yeast or bacterial growth, pathogen, parasite, adrenal dysfunction, or low HC—sometimes many of these contributing factors.

Is it IBS that can’t be resolved, or are you just in a system not designed to be able to help you?

Want to know more? Leave your questions below.

If you’ve been following along in my stories, you know that I’m currently completing a nutrition rotation in the ICU.

I knew I would learn a lot, but here are the most unexpected reminders and lessons that I’ve received.

Being able to walk, sleep, and breathe on your own is such an incredible gift. I never want to take this for granted again. 
How incredibly lucky I am to know that if an emergency were to ever strike, I would have people at my bedside praying for me, and how important support and love are in healing. Not everyone is so lucky or dealt a great hand in life, and that’s been heartbreaking to witness.

The perfect time to work on your health or go after that big life goal doesn’t exist. I’ve been thinking a lot about the things in life that I would regret not doing if I were lying in an ICU bed. Life never waits for you to be ready or for the right time. The perfect time is actually right now.

Are elimination diets like Low FODMAP or AIP helpful for certain people for short-term symptom relief?
Possibly. I’ll never take any tools off the table, but what’s your end game? If you don’t have a plan in place to exit your elimination diet, that’s a big red flag. 🚩🚩🚩

Are elimination diets a long-term strategy to heal your gut?
No.

If there’s one thing I wish more people knew about gut health, it’s this: long-term elimination diets don’t actually fix the problem in your gut or improve clinical results. In fact, long-term use of elimination diets may damage your gut over time due to a potential decrease in microbiome diversity.

Fixing the problem means addressing the underlying gut dysfunction that is contributing to your symptoms in the first place.

Elimination diets don’t do this. If you’re using an elimination diet as the primary strategy for your digestive symptoms, you’ll likely stay stuck in a never-ending cycle of one round of elimination diets after the next every time your symptoms pop up. 

What to do instead? Address any bacterial overgrowth and areas of the digestive tract that aren’t functioning as they should be. How to do that? Head to the 🔗🔗🔗 in my bio to schedule an assessment call.

Sometimes, the perfect medicine finds you if you’re open to receiving it.

I couldn’t think of a better remedy for the last couple of years than an extended weekend with limited Wi-Fi, frolicking in the river, dancing under the moonlight, and sharing communal meals.

In the quest for evidence-based care, let’s not forget about all the evidence that exists on the healing benefits of community and nature.

My client eliminated her IBS, constipation, loose stools, food anxiety, abdominal pain, skin rashes, and her symptoms by over 86% in just six months. 🤯🎉

🚨 Abdominal pain, which she described as debilitating and used to land her in the emergency room, and IBS symptoms that she had been dealing with for 10 years. 🚨

Here’s the four-step process we took:

Assessment
1️⃣ A detailed health history, diet assessment, and analysis of environmental and lifestyle factors. Imagine a 90-minute session where someone helps you begin to connect the dots.

Lab Testing
2️⃣ After her assessment, I made a plan to address the gaps in her data and the lab testing she was missing—things that had been overlooked for way too long. I looked at her mineral status, blood work, stool testing (💩), and the overall integrity of her gut. 🔬🥼

Personalized Nutrition
3️⃣ She got a personalized nutrition plan that involved focusing on whole, unprocessed foods and nutrients depleted in her body.

Her plan did NOT involve food sensitivity testing or overly restrictive diets. 🫢

While functional medicine has become synonymous with unnecessary elimination diets that force you to remove all the foods you commonly eat, in the second half of our time working together, we actually focused on adding foods into her diet. 🫢

Lifestyle Upgrades
4️⃣ One of the most commonly overlooked areas of GI health. A stressed gut and nervous system are an unhealthy digestive system. We focused on sleep hygiene, nervous system support, and regulating her circadian rhythm.

Oh, and did I mention she’s a busy mama and has a very demanding job?

Ready to correct your gut health? DM me “gut,” and I’ll show you how. 🌟

Are you constipated? 🤨💩

❌ While conventional medicine defines constipation as having fewer than three bowel movements per week, that’s not actually ideal or optimal. It’s the bare minimum, and nobody is thriving in life by focusing on the bare minimum.

Ideal Bowel Habits:
✔️ 1-3 painless bowel movements per day
✔️ Your bowel movements are well-formed, feel complete, and are easy to pass
✔️ Your stool doesn’t float in the toilet, you’re not in the bathroom forever, and there’s minimal mess on the toilet paper after wiping (yup, I went there) 🧻
✔️ No hard stool
✔️ No straining
✔️ No “rabbit pellets”

How do your habits stack up? How many ideal bowel habits do you check off?

One mistake I see all the time is jumping straight to the gut. The gut is not the place to start.

Digestion happens from north to south.

Digestion starts in the brain and then moves to the churning gastric juices and onto the release of pancreatic enzymes essential for digesting fats, carbohydrates, and protein.

Bloating, constipation, and undigested food in your stools are all symptoms that start before food ever hits your gut.

Failure to correct any breakdowns in the upper digestive tract will keep you stuck in a cycle of frustrating GI symptoms.

Here’s the gut health-promoting Turkey Day leftover you want to stock up on…

…cranberries.

Cranberries are rich in polyphenols. Polyphenols feed the good bacteria in your gut, but cranberries, in particular, may also boost the growth of bacteria in your gut called Akkermansia.

Akkermansia plays an important role in metabolic health, glucose control, overall digestive health, and maintaining the integrity of your gut lining.

Many clients I work with inside my clinic are particularly low in this gut bacteria.

So while cranberries are easily accessible in most stores right now, stock up, throw them in your freezer, and add a handful or two into your morning smoothie to help promote Akkermansia levels.

One thing I wish everyone struggling with their digestive health knew so you can stop wasting so much time...

Food sensitivities are not the root cause.

Are your symptoms real? Absolutely.

Can food trigger certain symptoms? Absolutely.

Does diet play a role in resolving gut issues? Yes.

However, food sensitivities are a symptom of underlying dysfunction in your gut. Not a root cause.

Ever notice how you can eat something and be fine one day, and the same food causes massive bloating, gas, and loose stools the next?

It’s because most of the time, it’s not the food that’s driving your gut issues.

Underlying causes of food sensitivities? Poor digestive function, gut permeability, SIBO, and bacterial dysbiosis, to name a few.

The underlying causes of food sensitivities will differ from person to person, but they absolutely must be addressed to resolve your bloating, gas, fatigue, and constipation.

Here’s the advice I’d give my younger self when I was first starting out on my journey to heal Hashimoto’s and all of the GI and nervous system symptoms that came along with it 12 years ago. I’m often an early adopter when it comes to healthcare. 
1.) Supplements alone won’t heal you. They are an extremely helpful tool that will assist you, but alone, they won’t achieve the results you are looking for. You can stop ordering everything you see someone write about (it was magazines and blogs back in the day because millennial here🙋🏻‍♀️) 
2.) Stop running 30+ miles every week. Running can be great, and I’m so happy you found a fitness outlet and a new community to be a part of, but your thyroid and adrenals need time to heal. Running that much while trying to heal is likely exacerbating your symptoms. 
3.) Stop waiting and stop trying to piece things together. I know investing in yourself can feel so scary because you were only taught to look for providers who took your insurance, but your symptoms are only going to get worse the longer you try to do it yourself, and you’ll miss out on so much. Everything you do, even when it doesn’t work out as you thought, will be so worth it in the end. 
4.) Hire the right support to help you work on nutrition, nervous system, and lifestyle changes because your functional and integrative medicine doctors are only looking at labs, and that’s only 40% of the picture. You’re only getting 40% better because you are only doing 40% of the work.

What did I miss? What advice would you give your younger self on your health journey?
What did I miss, friends? What would you add to the above?

Here’s how I helped my client eliminate her chronic loose stools and fatigue after years of trying everything else.

Maybe you’re just like my client too.

She felt like she was doing EVERYTHING her GI and functional medicine doctor told her to do.

She had a colonoscopy.

She didn’t drink alcohol for three months.

She cut out sugar.

Then dairy.

Then tried cutting out the 40 different foods that she was told to based on food sensitivity testing.

At the end of the day—after all of this restriction—she was still dealing with hormone imbalances, constant migraines, and chronic loose stools and felt like the root cause of her symptoms was still not being addressed.

The thing that finally shifted her health?

The answer may surprise you.

It wasn’t working on her gut health directly.

It wasn’t more restriction and figuring out how to make cutting out 40 different foods “less overwhelming” because you can’t. It is overwhelming.

It was taking a step back from the extremely restrictive and overwhelming diet she was put on and instead focusing on the forgotten fundamentals of GI health: her adrenal health, blood sugar balance, minerals, sleep, and meal hygiene— the most essential aspects of gut health that are far too often missing, and you can’t heal without.

Digestion starts in the brain, and it happens from north to south. Meaning, if you’re skipping over the first steps in the digestive process, you’re going to have problems lower in the GI tract as well.

Seeing, smelling, and then chewing your food are the first steps in the digestive process that most people miss.

You need proper north-to-south digestion leading to the large intestine to have a healthy microbiome.

If the north-to-south process is broken, you’re likely going to end up with symptoms like gas, bloating, lower abdominal pain, constipation, fatigue, and loose stools.

Believe me, I get it; stress management doesn’t come easy to me either. Years into functional medicine, and it’s still something I need to hold myself accountable for.

Not focusing on this might even be one of the reasons you’re still struggling with your gut health.
